title: Halle shooting: 'Gunman' arrested after livestreaming killings near German synagogue

A man has been arrested after allegedly live-streaming the killing of two people outside a German synagogue.

The attack occurred in the German city of Halle on on Yom Kippur today - Judaism's holiest day today.

The shooter live-streamed the attack in which he threw a grenade into a Jewish cemetery and left explosives near the synagogue after failing to force his way inside.

The suspect has been named by Bild as 27-year-old Stephan Balliet.

Police said: "Our forces have arrested one person. Still stay alert. We have strong forces in and around Halle and stabilize the situation until all information is secured."

The shooter allegedly ranted about feminism and immigration while wearing military fatigues and a helmet camera.

A woman was then shot dead outside the synagogue where around 80 people were praying.

(Image: ATV-Studio Halle/AFP via Getty I)

(Image: TWITCH/AFP via Getty Images)

Another man was then shot dead after the gunman drove to a kebab shop close to the synagogue before opening fire a second time.

Witnesses said the attacker used a submachine gun and threw a grenade into the Jewish cemetery, leaving people injured.

Konrad Rösler, 28, a railway employee, told publication Bild: "I stood in the doner shop. You have the man in army clothes with rifle. Then he threw something that looked like a grenade.

"But it was more like a Pollenböller. The thing has rebounded in the door frame. Then he shot into the glass.

"I found a toilet and locked myself up there. Then I heard another bang. At some point I heard the police and I made myself known and went out."

(Image: ATV-Studio Halle/AFP via Getty I)

(Image: REUTERS)

A blood-covered taxi driver was also reportedly rushed to hospital by air ambulance after he tried to stop the suspects from fleeing in his car.

His wife was also injured and is in hospital too.

Police urged people to stay inside as they tracked down the shooter.

Residents were warned of the incident via an app which urged people to stay away from windows and doors.

The filming of Wednesday's attack echoed another horrific shooting halfway around the world, when a far-right white supremacist in March killed 51 people at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand and livestreamed much of the attack on Facebook.

That massacre drew strong criticism of social media giants for not immediately finding and blocking such a violent video.

It said: "Firearms use in urban areas. Do not leave buildings and apartments away from windows and doors. Notes: Turn on radio and television."

(Image: dpa/AFP via Getty Images)

(Image: dpa/AFP via Getty Images)

Dr. Nora Goldenbogen, 70, chairman of the Jewish community in Dresden, said: "This terrible act shocks us deeply. So far, we always felt safe, there was no evidence that we were in danger."

German chancellor Angela Merkel attended an evening vigil at a historic synagogue in central Berlin in honour of the victims.

Mrs Merkel condemned the shooting, her spokesman saying she offered "solidarity for all Jews on the holy day of Yom Kippur".

The Chancellor had "deep sympathy" for the victims' families, government spokesman Steffen Seibert said, adding her 'thanks to all the security forces who are still on the scene'.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu also condemned the attack, saying it was "a new expression of anti-Semitism on the rise in Europe".
